body:
@ronjouch would this address #330 and #348 (partially)?

EDIT: Confirmed! Adding `StartupWMClass=Alacritty` to the end of my Alacritty.desktop file and saving it _immediately_ fixes the icon issues mentioned in #330 without even restarting the process for me on Ubuntu 16.10. Commenting out that line and restarting alacritty #330 occurs again.
I actually have a patch for setting wm_class separately, but I decided against it since it's already set by the title. Should we set wm_class independently? Seems like that workaround would be fine.

issue.title: Ubuntu 16.10: Alacritty.desktop opens unstyled separate icon on launcher
issue.body:
## Goal

I want to add Alacritty as a pinned icon on my launcher using a custom logo.

## Background

I'm on Ubuntu 16.10, and I've add copied this Alacritty.desktop to my `~/.local/share/applications/`:

```
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
TryExec=/usr/local/bin/alacritty
Exec=/usr/local/bin/alacritty
Icon=custom-logo
Terminal=false
X-Catagories=System;TerminalEmulator
Name=Alacritty
GenericName=Terminal
Comment=A cross-platform, GPU enhanced terminal emulator
```

I've also copied `custom-logo.png` to `/usr/share/pixmaps/`

I copied the Alacritty.desktop icon to the launcher, and the custom logo appears in the launcher as expected.

## Problem

Cicking on the logo causes a separate entry to appear on the launcher.  See screenshots:

![before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/220106/22157399/680438ca-deec-11e6-9eeb-12f46a3286ec.png)

![after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/220106/22157408/6e4a2bf4-deec-11e6-9d87-ce042a5843f9.png)

body: @jwilm I'd vote to include `StartupWMClass=Alacritty` in the .desktop file for now and create an issue to refactor later (if desired). I'm happy to open a PR for that one line change.

issue.title: (fix) Associates .desktop file with running process in Linux desktop OSes

body: I am still getting a blanc icon. Any suggestions?

`.desktop` files will probably work more reliably once winit implements the [startup notification protocol](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/startup-notification-spec/startup-notification-0.1.txt), though I haven't been able to verify that yet.

Okay, startup notification doesn't seem to make a difference. I did figure some other stuff out, though.

Tips:
- Always install `.desktop` files to `/usr/local/share/applications` rather than `~/.local/share/applications`, since the latter isn't always searched.
- Be sure to delete any existing `Alacritty.desktop` from `~/.local/share/applications`, since somehow it didn't work until after I did that.
- The `.desktop` filename should be the same as the binary filename, so `alacritty.desktop`.

Following that, the icon shows up correctly for me now.

@francesca64 I don't use `.desktop` files, but do you think it would make sense to put these tips into the `README` maybe?

If you think it makes sense and have the time to open a PR, I'd welcome it very much. :)

@chrisduerr yeah, I'll be able to do that, though I'm not done researching the problem yet. It's unfortunately tricky, since there are heuristics in place that make it hard to tell when we're doing something incorrectly.

I've got it working perfectly with my own application, but for some reason Alacritty's icon only wants to show up in `latte-dock` and `cairo-dock`, and not in `plank`. It's not a big deal though, so I'll submit a PR even if I don't figure that out.

Installing `.desktop` files manually seems to be a bad idea. Detection worked more reliably once I switched to using the utils:
```bash
sudo desktop-file-install alacritty.desktop
sudo update-desktop-database
```
